Predicting death from cardiovascular disease before individuals are identified is a challenge for healthcare providers.
What is the purpose of predictive modeling for mortality?
Predictive modelling is a method (for example that of calculating an odds ratio and comparing the odds of diagnosis for the two groups) that uses previously observed outcomes that are in fact influenced by current conditions. In many of the world’s diseases, this includes mortality. The outcome of the treatment being trialed can be predicted using the risk for that specific disease for people of the same age and gender (e.g. for cancer, which has a high survival rate). As well as for CVD, predictive modelling may also be used for cardiovascular health and other medical conditions where the likelihood of an event is not known until the end of the research period. Predictive modelling is usually a stage in a clinical trial. In some trials, for example, a randomized clinical trial, predictive modelling may be used together with a patient cohort to determine treatment preferences in patients who have been identified to be at a higher risk of disease.
What are the limitations of predictive modelling? In general, the potential for bias and/or errors is a major consideration. For some models, such as those designed for mortality, one may find that the same set of outcomes predicts different results in people on two different treatments. In such patients, or in patients on certain tests that do not have good repeatability, using the predictive models may lead to erroneous outcomes, with additional potential risks.
What is a risk factor?
When examining potential risk factors for cardiovascular disease, a risk factor is one that increases the chance of developing a disease by increasing its risk. It is important to consider the risk factors for cardiovascular disease for patients on different treatments, including for CVD, for example.
Predicting mortality may be most effective when there are no known or significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease. In such patients, using a few variables that may predict mortality may reduce bias. Potential confounding bias is a problem with this approach and should be addressed by consulting with one’s own doctor.
What is a binary response?
Some clinical outcomes, such as mortality, may be very difficult to predict through a patient-cohort model because the outcomes may change from day to day or month to month. The data that could be obtained in this case may be very difficult to collect and that are also very difficult to predict. Because of this, it is therefore important that any use of predictive modelling be accompanied by a model that can account for this type of variability.
What factors are considered to be important in predicting mortality?
Several independent (and often conflicting) sources have been used to estimate mortality rates for specific disease groups for various cause-specific mortality events. These include mortality, specific disease, and cohort-based data. In this exercise, we will focus on mortality, specifically, in relation to disease.
In an exploratory analysis, we will take a patient-cohort approach and look at the individual factors that are associated with mortality (see below).
In a hierarchical analysis, we will try to estimate individual mortality rates that combine the characteristics of mortality and a disease-specific mortality event (Mixed-Mortality-Specificity).
How do risk factors influence mortality?
Predictive modelling is helpful for understanding disease pathogenesis and for understanding the relationship between risk factors and mortality, but it also has to be done within a more robust population and more complex data set. The aim is to build an accurate model that accounts for all aspects of complex human disease and life processes that may influence mortality.
How do risk factors affect mortality?
Predictive modelling can be used to create models in which the predictor variables in the model are the factors affecting mortality. The predictor variables are the specific disease or condition that is being studied, and the factors could be lifestyle factors or other variables, such as a doctor’s diagnosis such as hypertension, a BMI or smoking status.
Predictive models can be particularly useful when using data from health surveys. Surveys generate a large number of questions that may be missing some individuals, for example. It is a complex clinical question, with different approaches to address it. Firstly, the assessment is the simple assessment of the general and specific health related factor, which often include other clinical factors (such as the history of diabetes). For this assessment, NICE considers both the measurement of the general and specific health related factor of the patient group and their risk of CVD. The risk of CVD is assessed based on the definition of CVD in the EHS guidelines (see below). Secondly, with the aim of helping physicians, the NICE guidelines recommend that the person should get a comprehensive risk assessment of CVD, where all co-morbid risk factors are assessed. The NIS of a person does not provide the means for achieving the most up to date cardiovascular risk assessment (e.g., in the EHS model), so some patients may require a more detailed and detailed assessment of the risk of CVD based on the results of individual tests. Thirdly, in addition to the established NIS of the individual patient (e.g., the T2N estimate for the person), the NICE guidelines also suggest a more thorough and accurate risk assessment of CVD that involves the use of blood pressure monitors to measure the blood pressure of a group of patients with CVD. The risk of CVD is assessed using two simple approaches (see Table 1) of blood pressure measurement. The blood pressure measurement of the individual patient is performed by having an individual patient’s blood pressure measured in a single room with their own monitor, which can be a gold standard for patients of this type. To improve the accuracy of the systolic or diastolic blood pressure measurement, the use of pulse wave technology has been suggested. The pulse wave technology is more precise in detecting the systolic or diastolic systolic blood pressure, as well as the T2N estimate of the BP based on the whole blood pressure (12/61 mmHg). (These algorithms differ in the use of the cuff in different countries.) Thus, the systolic or diastolic blood pressure of the patient can be obtained easily without a blood pressure cuff and with low cost and convenience.

Answer: Heart health is one of the most neglected risk factors for disease of all, and no one should be left behind. While many experts agree that heart health is a critical part of overall health, it is not always easy to identify. The NICE recommendation that everyone should maintain the lowest LDL cholesterol and highest HDL cholesterol levels of 4-5 by 2025 is one element of the NHS's comprehensive lifestyle change strategy to improve heart health. With such a long and challenging life, taking charge of one's health should be something to focus on. While it is likely that many factors such as lifestyle habits will influence the outcome, the NHS guidelines are a solid foundation and the NHS encourages everyone to use it to improve their health and wellbeing.
Dr Tom Chuang, clinical lead and chief clinical officer of the NICE guideline update program, said: “This guidance outlines some of the common risks to the quality and quantity of the blood, which some patients face on a daily basis. The current focus is on high cholesterol levels, diabetes and smoking. It does not cover everyone or any one type, so it should suit all people who want an understanding to take control of their health now and look after their own health in the future.”
Dr Chris Dickson, consultant cardiologist at the University of Leicester and lead clinician on this guideline update, said “This guideline will help doctors, teachers and patients to be more self-aware about their health, to identify and assess individual and family risk for disease and help prevent the diseases that most severely impact on their lives. The guide will help patients work with their family, friends and healthcare providers to develop a plan to improve their health. It will also ensure patients are better prepared and equipped to tackle the challenges of a healthier lifestyle.”
NHS and NICE have launched a new partnership which is designed to bring together NHS leadership and healthcare professional experts to identify new evidence-based strategies to improve patient care and outcomes.
The partnership, The NHS Alliance for Improved Care, has developed a strategy to ensure that quality improvement programs such as NHS blood pressure check services in England get extra funding and resources. It is designed to maximise the benefits of a health system that is better placed to manage blood pressure.
NHS England and NICE collaborated on this work, which will be available before the end of the year. However, the guidance will be more widely used for patients and their health care professionals.
NHS England has launched a new website, NHS England Action Online, offering information that provides guidance to health professionals, patients, and their families, who want to get more in-depth knowledge about their health and the potential effects of interventions.
It is being driven by the NHS Action Online team, which advises employers and healthcare professionals to ensure they meet the minimum performance criteria and to communicate effectively with each other and the broader network on the need for improved outcomes for their staff members.

This question is at the heart of a complex and multi-dimensional problem that is still largely unknown. The following recommendations were developed to support healthcare professionals in their efforts to use NICE guidelines to improve CVD prevention. The key considerations are those in Box 1.
The focus of recent research into the development of strategies for CVD prevention is to identify what patients can already do to significantly improve their risk. Whilst some of these strategies are well established, there are a growing number of new strategies which would be expected to have a significant positive impact in reducing CVD risk.
Cardiology practice
The main goal of treatment for CVD is to reduce the risk of further morbidity and mortality. This aim is known as the “safeguarding of individuals – improving cardiovascular health”, and is best achieved by improving the condition of individuals.
In order to implement CVD prevention strategies, the focus must align with the principles of healthcare. This is because while efforts are being made, and evidence generated, at this point there is still uncertainty about what strategies are clinically appropriate and whether existing guidelines can apply.
At the time of writing, there is little guidance available to clinicians from outside of the NICE health areas to support their use in CVD prevention. This is especially true when considering the need for individualised risk assessment, rather than general recommendations.
For the patient, there is a high likelihood of the practitioner becoming less informed if they are unable to interpret the results from tests and/or have no information to provide. The most common way of obtaining information on a patient's risk of future CVD is through medical referrals. However, even if a patient is unable to provide the full range of information, a clinician is still able to interpret findings as guidance and therefore assist with clinical decision making.
In the context of patient self-reporting, the benefits of including open-ended questions such as “What is the one thing that you have found most surprising/concerning/helpful?” was greater than those based on the specific instructions given and has now been shown to increase patient satisfaction (Pg273).
Despite the apparent benefits, there are a number of limitations within the current evidence base. Research into how individuals can be risk-reduced from the most trivial factors to the most significant risk factors has been limited, and the evidence was lacking in terms of understanding the impact of individual risk factors. However, one important limitation is that the individual-level risk assessment is made by using a clinician's judgement. In many instances, the clinician's assessment of individual risk is an incomplete assessment of what could change in the individual or their individual choices if it were appropriate.
Furthermore, the clinical judgement based on risk assessment has been shown to be a poor guide to practice. This is especially true for those who are likely to be at high risk of CVD as they represent an extremely small group of the general population. Clinicians are not equipped to make the decisions about how to increase the likelihood of CVD risk, they could make any decision based on the likelihood of their patient's being at risk, but it is a more accurate indication of this risk than the clinician can make their judgements about their patient.
Ultimately, there is much more that we need to understand about preventing CVD to support our clinical practice on a more routine and more cost-effective basis.

However, it is a very general rule; even having a high BMI in a family can be associated with a high CVD risk in offspring, because children of those with the highest BMI are also the highest risk children.
Therefore, family history is not a definitive explanation of cardiovascular risk, but it is an important factor in our assessment and prevention of cardiovascular disease and so represents an important area in which new interventions addressing those who would not otherwise benefit from risk can be considered.

There are a number of recommendations about which to focus, and some guidelines are not aligned with the NICE standards. The first recommendation is to increase physical activity (including walking, gardening, and housework) by about 500 minutes per week to reduce cardiovascular risk (the recommendation is “dietary intervention”), and then to reduce total energy intake by 300 kilocalorie per day. There are no specific CVD prevention steps that are recommended in this approach.
For 10 years, most doctors, nurses, and the national government have recommended that most adults eat five servings of fruit and vegetables per day. However, few have followed the recommendations for fruit and vegetables. Most doctors recommend a three-ounce size serving of fruit and/or vegetables to reduce CVD risk, based on 500 kilocalorie recommendations. In addition, the recommendations have two additional recommendations that have no support – for the “obesity” diet and for weight loss in persons with obesity (BMI 30 or higher). In addition, the recommended number of servings of fruit, vegetable, and dairy (35 oz.) has been used as a guideline in the US instead of 5 servings. But what happens when more than 5 servings?!
The first example of the “obesity” diet was introduced into America many years ago by an American woman named Betty Friedan. When she and her husband, James, and son used it to promote their home-cooking program, it led to an outbreak of obesity and raised the national number of obesity deaths by 1,600 per year in 1970. Unfortunately, the idea was rejected by the British Medical Association and several other medical authorities. As a result, the recommendations became a national policy and have been made mandatory for many more years, including at the federal level. In 2014, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) issued this “new diet” advice. A study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), in 2013, found that most of the people who ate the recommended amount, the equivalent of three servings of fruit, did so to reduce their CVD mortality. But what about 5 servings of fruit and vegetables? Could that lead to a much less effective advice (or recommendations) to prevent CVD and reduce CVD mortality? As a result, it is now recommended that the recommended amount of servings of fruit and vegetables should be increased – particularly “carrots” – to reduce CVD mortality.
Also in this view of CVD prevention, experts and the media have given a warning about the “fat diet”. The “fat diet” is designed to promote weight loss in order to lower cholesterol levels – such as the one that promoted by the American physician Dr. Robert Wood Johnson. There are no guidelines about what is considered a “fat” person and, of course, the media will take the advice of Dr. Wood Johnson away. These recommendations are also based on low levels of HDL cholesterol (a precursor to CVD – see here for a discussion). In addition, the recommendations also promote a “bad” fats in general. Studies to date have shown that saturated fat is associated with an increased risk of heart attack, a heart attack is an increased risk of stroke, and a heart attack is an increased risk of heart disease and death, but more research is needed in this area.
The “fat diet” was promoted by Dr. Robert Wood Johnson, and the US Centers for Disease Control (CDC) as something “healthful” for the body to limit the fat in. What if I would also need lifestyle therapy? Does that count?
You must do a basic assessment, based on the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute guidelines. These are general guidelines that should be used as a starting point, not a hard and fast law. Remember that these guidelines are based on scientific knowledge, and they are not the final word on treatment of CVD.
As we get to know a person or a clinical decision, we can do a bit less work than a simple clinical assessment. We need to know their risk factors, their history of cardiovascular disease, and have an objective relationship with their risk factors. We get to do a bunch of simple tests, and look to see whether the person is at risk. This can be done with a simple self-examinatory test, e.g. a normal cholesterol level. We can do a detailed history, together with a physical exam, and test the individual to see if they have other risk factors, e.g. hypertension, diabetes, and obesity.
If people have the same symptoms as those with heart disease, then there may be a common risk factor. Our objective would be to determine whether a few common risk factors are the same, or different. I would be asking someone to think of a risk factor together with a more specific one, in order to arrive at a more specific recommendation. I would try to obtain 30 seconds' (informal) of each item listed, so that all the data is collected before the 2 questions are asked. After this, we would look to see if we were close. The more specific our recommendation is, the better. We can't do this every time. That is the rule of thumb in our case.
I'm going to call these simple interventions, and we can use an example of one of them: a simple exercise program. If you exercise, your blood pressure and cholesterol will decrease. We can do that for just a week, and then repeat the process, if necessary. Or we can just do the exercise test. It really depends on the person's level of fitness, and how much they are willing to do this risk reduction exercise.
After the simple intervention test, we can look at the results together. If what happens is the same, what do we expect to happen? Would it help or hurt the person? Would they notice any changes after the simple exercise routine? Would we still be doing it? Could they follow the exercise? What about a simple lifestyle decision? Could they make lifestyle changes or not, such as not smoking?
What about some individual who, before the intervention, was at a very high risk of CVD? What about 50-year-olds with at least 8 risk factors?
The most important first step in improving care of people with CVD is to know their risk factors – and to know where best to start. We should be taking the information on this disease to people we care about, to inform them about the best ways to maintain their cardiac health.
There are already people in England who have been given the same advice about what lifestyle changes we could make to improve their cardiovascular risk over several years, and we can use this information and what we have learned, to inform more people in this area, about lifestyle changes they can make to make a positive difference. The more we know, the better. We all have a responsibility to help others who are in their 70s and beyond become the best people we can be.

Treatment for atrial fibrillation
In atrial fibrillation, when the abnormal contractions are too numerous and too noisy, the heart will be in cardiac failure. If there are no changes in medication, you should be monitored for these problems regularly.
Treatments and drugs
A simple noninvasive approach to treating atrial fibrillation is to use atrial fibrillation-selective suture-repair (ASSR) to treat a smaller portion of the heart tissue.
A cardiac surgeon will perform an ASSR. These procedures will most likely be an outpatient operation, although you also may be fitted with a pacemaker. If your heart is not beating normally, an implantable cardioverter defibrillator may also be suggested.
This is more common in older adults and is intended to replace a faulted or malfunctioning heart muscle. It sends electrical impulses to the heart muscle that may have been damaged.
This is a more invasive device called a cardioverter with pacemaker (CVP). This device contains electrodes placed on the body. The chambers of the myocardium are stimulated with small electrical shocks to regulate the electrical impulses sent to the heart from the pacemaker. If electrical instability in the heart is caused by abnormal rhythm, atrial fibrillation is often the problem. There is also potential harm to the implanted heart, such as the possibility of a heart valve replacement or serious damage to a healthy portion of the heart.
There is a pacemaker in atrial fibrillation to maintain electrical activity in the heart, but it is usually not used until the fibrillation has been unresponsive to medications.
An artificial heart
If your heart is unable to beat normally, an artificial heart can be implanted to replace the heart muscle. The implant can be surgically implanted into the body within minutes. The device may then pump muscle tissue from your chest to your lungs so that your heart doesn't beat too strongly at times.
The heart may not beat enough to pump blood around the body if there is a blood clot. For this reason, an artificial heart can help prevent heart attacks.
An atrial fibrillation pacemaker is not an essential piece of equipment in many general practices, but it may be used to prolong the time between heartbeats and help prevent an arrhythmia.
There are different brands of pacemakers available.
- A total cardioversion is a procedure that uses pacing devices made by the company FACEPAM.
- A pacemaker that stimulates the heart muscle is a pacemaker that is implanted by an anesthesiologist.
- A pacemaker is a device that keeps pacemaker electrodes in place under the skin of the chest area. The device can also be implanted in the groin area.
- The heart is a muscle and a pacemaker can only send electrical impulses to the heart muscle in a way that is meant to affect a certain portion of it.
- An atrial fibrillation pacemaker may be used in certain heart rhythm disturbances, such as atrial fibrillation that is associated with a dangerous arrhythmia, for emergency cardiac intervention.
- A cardiac pacemaker is a device designed to regulate the heart's rhythm.

The goal of all these recommendations is to help people prevent cardiovascular disease.
The advice by NICE comes at a time of heightened public health attention on global tobacco control—some 3 million cases of secondhand smoke exposure from tobacco products, plus 100,000,000 registered smoker deaths per year.
It's an unprecedented challenge, especially in the UK where the number of deaths from cancer—due primarily to smoking—is now 14 times the combined average for the developed world.
What is happening in the UK?
The global number of smokers is rising. Worldwide, tobacco industry profits have increased in recent years and new tobacco products reach the market.
But the biggest threats to people's health are new ones.
The current smoking guidelines do not address the impact of chronic diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, heart disease, or stroke, nor does they address the economic burden these diseases cause.
The Global Economic Impact of Tobacco, a report by IES, a UK think tank, estimated that tobacco control policies can save the UK economy more than £7 billion by 2030. The report also estimated that smoking-related deaths are predicted to increase 29% in 2025.
The UK is now home to more than 721,000 smokers in the UK. However, those numbers will nearly double in 2027—which represents an over-reporting of the true number of smokers.
The majority of these smokers will be young adults or people with chronic conditions who smoke for reasons beyond personal knowledge or experience:
- In the first three years after their first cigarette—before the first effects of the nicotine itself have worn off or the withdrawal symptoms, and they experience the first day smoking again—most will start smoking again.
- Within about four years after their first cigarette, they will smoke 10 times more cigarettes in a year compared to a control group.
- And within six years they will also be smokers (47% vs 50%) or have first-degree relatives who are smokers (58% vs. 26%).
The risk of becoming a second-hand smoker in the UK is also rising over time.
It follows that the UK's population would likely bear a greater, if not identical, burden of tobacco disease, which is one of the main economic burden of smoking.
If it were a country that put a whole in one place, it would be a country that would be 32 times the amount of people who die from cancer, high blood pressure and heart disease.
How does tobacco get to this UK-like population?
Smoke is spread across the UK by fires, roads, and highways.
The most widely used form is cigarettes, which account for 41% of British smoking. Second-hand smoke from matches and candles affects the same proportion of people who smoke.
Methamphetamine is also a major contributing factor to tobacco addiction and its global uptake: 475,000 people use a methamphetamin device (e.g. meth-i) in the UK.
And, as more people use these devices, smoking becomes more and more widely accepted.
But the risks of using these devices far outweigh the benefits:
- Methamphetamin users are almost twice as likely to die of a smoking related emergency as methphetamine users.
- Methamphetamine also acts as a stimulant, encouraging people to smoke faster and further.
- Methamphetamine is banned in China, Vietnam, and Afghanistan. It is used in these countries in 35 different ways, such as in powder powders.
- Methamphetamin users have about 13 times the risk of developing heart disease, stroke, type 2 diabetes, high blood pressure, and chronic lung disease as the non-methamphetamin users.
We also know that people who have first-hand exposure to secondhand smoke are also at greater risk of tobacco-related disease.
The effects of these exposures are cumulative: if someone is exposed to 2.5 cigarettes a day for a month, the cumulative probability of developing some specific disease increases to between 5.5 and 10.5%.
And if someone is exposed to twice as many cigarettes per day, that probability increases to more than 14.
Who will become a smoker first?
Smoking-related diseases and deaths are disproportionately higher in younger people. That means younger people are increasingly susceptible to the side-effects of nicotine.

NICE guidelines give advice according to the most scientifically proven, scientifically accepted ways to prevent and minimise the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD). The guidelines aim to make people in their 20s (men for age 40-60, women for age 50-64) who are at high risk of CVD have access to tools and resources based on these recommendations.
For NICE, CVD is an umbrella term for a range of conditions that affect the heart, blood vessels, blood pressures and platelets, blood fats or sugars. It involves high cholesterol, heart disease, stroke, kidney disease, blood (intravascular), diabetes, coronary artery disease and more, all these are conditions that require careful monitoring as well as prevention. Having any of these or other conditions combined means at risk for CVD.
If you’re at risk for CVD, have been tested for a known genetic cause, or have a family history of CVD, NICE recommends having a cardiovascular risk score (CRS) test. These tests look at how likely you are to develop heart disease and stroke. For example, a factor analysis, looking at the risk factors of the 10 most commonly found SNPs, might give a genetic link to coronary artery disease.
NICE says a cardiovascular risk score from a simple blood pressure measurement is only justifiable because 5 to 10 heart attacks can happen in just 1 year’s time, after which one may become dependent on non-pharmacological treatment to avoid strokes or heart failure. A cardiovascular risk score can also be used to find a link between the genetic cause of specific diseases or genetic variants in family members with known at-risk conditions. For example, a genetic variant that increases the risk of heart attack could be linked to a person’s at-risk genetic variation.
For certain patients with no family history of CVD, it is not only important to screen but could also be done without any involvement of a hospital.
